For investors outside the United States, buying U.S. stocks is rarely simple. Many face restricted brokerage access, long onboarding processes, tax forms, proof of address checks, and expensive currency conversions. 

Even after all that, access is often limited and slow. These barriers do not protect investors. They quietly exclude them and keep global capital locked out of opportunity.

Why @idOS_network matters (and how it wins)

Let‚Äôs be clear: idOS isn‚Äôt creating a new market. It‚Äôs fixing one of the most broken and expensive ones in finance.

Financial institutions spend $200‚Äì$280B every year on onboarding, KYC, and compliance.

For big banks, that‚Äôs already 5‚Äì8% of their budget. For fintechs and stablecoin-native players? It‚Äôs way worse:

20‚Äì25% of total operating costs burned on compliance and identity.

Compliance has become a regressive tax
especially for stablecoin startups.

DeFi composability allows stablecoin neobanks to stack:
‚Ä¢ onramps
‚Ä¢ cards
‚Ä¢ virtual accounts
‚Ä¢ financial modules

‚Ä¶all under one interface.
But the whole thing breaks the moment users have to re-KYC every time they switch a module.

Mainstream users won‚Äôt accept that.
They loved neobanks for UX not for repeating identity checks inside the same app.

This is the real blocker for scaling the stablecoin economy.

The solution is obvious:
Seamless, compliant KYC re-usability

That‚Äôs exactly where idOS comes in.
It‚Äôs the beachhead into the massive onboarding, verification, and compliance market built for Web3 scale.

Revenue model is simple and aligned:
‚Ä¢ Protocol fees
‚Ä¢ Service fees

Fix the identity layer ‚Üí unlock composability ‚Üí unlock growth.

This is infrastructure. And it‚Äôs overdue with @idOS_network
